pageProps.contentHtml:
normal families

Let FM\mathcal{F}_MFM​ be the set of functions holomorphic on D\DD and continuous on D‾\cl{\D}D that satisfy

∫02π∣f(eit)∣ dt≤M<∞.\int_0^{2\pi} \abs{f\p{e^{it}}} \,\diff{t} \leq M < \infty.∫02π​∣∣​f(eit)∣∣​dt≤M<∞.

Show that every sequence {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ in FM\mathcal{F}_MFM​ contains a subsequence that converges uniformly on compact subsets of D\DD.
Solution.

It suffices to show that FM\mathcal{F}_MFM​ is a normal family, i.e., uniformly bounded on each compact set. Let 0<r<R<10 < r < R < 10<r<R<1 and f∈FMf \in \mathcal{F}_Mf∈FM​. Observe that fR(z)=f(Rz)f_R\p{z} = f\p{Rz}fR​(z)=f(Rz) is holomorphic on a neighborhood of D‾\cl{\D}D, so by the Cauchy integral formula, we have for any z∈B(0,r)‾z \in \cl{B\p{0, r}}z∈B(0,r)​ that

fR(z)=12πi∫∂DfR(ζ)ζ−z dζ  ⟹  ∣fR(z)∣≤12π∫02π∣fR(eiθ)∣1−r dθ.\begin{gathered} f_R\p{z} = \frac{1}{2\pi i} \int_{\partial \D} \frac{f_R\p{\zeta}}{\zeta - z} \,\diff\zeta \\ \implies \abs{f_R\p{z}} \leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \frac{\abs{f_R\p{e^{i\theta}}}}{1 - r} \,\diff\theta. \end{gathered}fR​(z)=2πi1​∫∂D​ζ−zfR​(ζ)​dζ⟹∣fR​(z)∣≤2π1​∫02π​1−r∣∣​fR​(eiθ)∣∣​​dθ.​

Notice that fR→ff_R \to ffR​→f everywhere on ∂D\partial\D∂D by continuity, so by uniform continuity on D‾\cl{\D}D, we may simply send R→1R \to 1R→1 to get

∣f(z)∣≤12π(1−r)∫02π∣f(eiθ)∣ dθ≤M2π(1−r).\abs{f\p{z}} \leq \frac{1}{2\pi\p{1 - r}} \int_0^{2\pi} \abs{f\p{e^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta \leq \frac{M}{2\pi\p{1 - r}}.∣f(z)∣≤2π(1−r)1​∫02π​∣∣​f(eiθ)∣∣​dθ≤2π(1−r)M​.

Since fff was arbitrary and the constant depends only on rrr, we see that FM\mathcal{F}_MFM​ is a normal family, so any sequence has a subsequence which converges locally uniformly on D\DD.
